fr:title.text: angle between a space-like and a time-like vector

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: angle between a space-like and a time-like vector

fr:mainmatter.html:p:
Given a wedge formed by two vectors a and b where a is space-like and b is time-like, we define the angle as
\angle a b = \ln \frac {a \cdot b + |a \times b|}{-i |a| \cdot |b|} - \frac {1}{2} \pi i.
This is the same formula as Definition , but we specify the factor of i in the denominator to contribute - \frac {1}{2} \pi i to the result.
We define the angle of a wedge in the Minkowski plane by a case analysis. The angle between two vectors are then defined by choosing a wedge between them in a consistent way.

fr:mainmatter.html:p:
Given a wedge formed by two vectors a and b contained in a space-like region, we define the angle as
\angle a b = \operatorname {arcosh} \frac {a \cdot b}{|a| \cdot |b|}.
Since \operatorname {arcosh} k = \ln (k + \sqrt {k^2 - 1}), we can re-express it using the cross product:
\angle a b = \ln \frac {a \cdot b + |a \times b|}{|a| \cdot |b|}.

This is the same formula as Definition , but we specify the factor of i in the denominator to contribute - \frac {1}{2} \pi i to the result.

Given a wedge formed by two vectors a and b contained in a time-like region, we define the angle as
\angle a b = - \ln \frac {a \cdot b - |a \times b|}{|a| \cdot |b|}.
Here both the numerator and the denominator are negative.

Such a definition is additive. Therefore, for more general angles, we can always break it up into smaller fragments, and the sum is well-defined. Under this convention a whole turn has total angle -2 \pi i.

Angles involving a null edge will be infinite. This has to do with the fact that they have zero geodesic length, although it is still meaningful to compare the ratio of lengths of null segments. If we specify a unit length of null segments, then it is possible to renormalize the infinite angles, giving a finite value, while retaining additivity.
